summary.p: This manuscript consists mostly of samples of Sāñcīpat, Agar wood bark prepared to be used as writing support. This practice is common in Assam. Most folios are blank, except for one which contains a few lines in Śāradā script. A note in Palmyr Cordier's hand describes the process by which the folios are prepared, translated into French from an 1894 article in the Journal of the Asiatic Society of Bengal by E. A. Gait.

The few lines of text comes from the seventh chapter of Ṣaṭsāhasrasaṃhitā. Although the text is unpublished, the verses in this manuscript are likely to be 65-67 (cf. Schoterman 1982, 218). Verses 65-66 closely parallel 4.111-112 of the Kubjikāmatatantra as edited by Goudriaan & Schoterman (1988, 191).
This manuscript seems to be copied from the same folio as Sanscrit 1442.3, which continues the text.
